text: Genesis chapter 33, we had some extra specials tonight, I shared the situation there about love thy neighbor, so you listen fast, I'm going to preach fast, amen? And we got a fellowship over in the other room after the service, and a farewell fellowship for Jared. We're going to look at the entirety of Genesis 33 this evening, but it's only 20 verses, and so not too bad, and trust the Lord to help us here. I've titled the message, as you look at the back of the bulletin there, from verse number 11, the Bible says in verse 11, take, I pray thee, my blessing that is brought to thee, because God hath dealt graciously with me, and because I have enough, and he urged him, and he took it. I'm telling the message this evening, God hath dealt graciously with me. Of course, as we looked at Genesis chapter number 32, that long, life-altering night that we studied a couple of weeks ago, we find the reunion between Jacob and Esau would finally come to pass. As we have noted, Jacob is quite concerned about this reunion. We understand that Jacob has departed from Paddan Aram to go back to the land of his fathers at the instruction, as a result of the instruction of the Lord. God had given him the instruction to return, and Jacob was obedient to that instruction, and we find that he's now going back, and he knows that he has to have this reunion with his brother. Of course, he had sent some men ahead in order to just prepare the way, and he found out that Esau was coming with 400 men, and he was quite concerned. And so, as we look at this text of Scripture, God records for us this account of this reunion between Jacob and Esau, and we find that within the text that Jacob makes that great declaration that God hath dealt graciously with me. I believe that this evening that each one of us could agree with Jacob, and we could understand that God has been gracious to us. He's been so, so good to us, and what a blessing to know the Lord. If you are taking notes this evening, number one, Jacob embraced his brother. In verses one through four, we see the reunion recorded for us, and what an amazing scene that God gives us. I'm thankful that God has recorded these verses of Scripture, this event in the life of Jacob, for it's certainly impactful. First the Bible begins in verse number one, and Jacob lifted up his eyes and looked, and behold, Esau came, and notice what it says, and with him 400 men. Now he'd already known that in the beginning of chapter 32, he'd received that intel report. The Bible continues, though, and says, and he, speaking of Jacob, divided the children unto Leah, and unto Rachel, and unto the two handmaids. Why did he do that? Remember, he was concerned that Esau was going to kill him, and also kill his wives and children. It says in verse number two, that he put the handmaids and their children foremost, and Leah and her children after, and Rachel and Joseph hindermost, and he passed over before them, and bowed himself to the ground seven times, until he came near to his brother. And I love verse number four, for the Bible says, and Esau ran to meet him, and embraced him, and fell on his neck, and kissed him, and they wept. Isn't that a beautiful account of this reunion between Jacob and his brother Esau, and we find that Jacob and Esau, there's an embrace. It tells us in verse number four that Esau runs to meet him, and now Esau, the last that we've heard of Esau with regard to his perspective of Jacob, is that he's going to kill Jacob. He was angry over the blessing and all that had taken place, but we find that nearly 20 years has passed since that time, and we find this great reunion. I believe that as we look at these few verses of Scripture that record for us this reunion and this embrace between Jacob and Esau, it's a great example and a great picture of forgiveness and reconciliation. So often I've said over the years that two pillars of biblical Christianity, and it's just two of many pillars of biblical Christianity, but two pillars of biblical Christianity are forgiveness and reconciliation. And I'm so thankful for the fact that we've been forgiven. Isn't it wonderful to know the forgiveness of God? The Bible says that with thee there is forgiveness. Our God is a God that's ready to pardon, He's ready to forgive, and as the people of God we understand something about forgiveness because we have been forgiven, and therefore we are to forgive others. The Bible says in Ephesians 4 and verse 32, "...and be kind one to another, tenderhearted, forgiving one another, even as God for Christ's sake hath forgiven you." I didn't deserve to be forgiven. It's God's grace and God's mercy that led to me being forgiven, and I'm so thankful that God is rich in mercy, that God's grace is amazing and it's abundant, and this evening we think about this truth of forgiveness, and then we think about reconciliation. What a joy to understand the truth of reconciliation. See, we've often spoken over the years, and yes, there's truth in the Bible with regard to church discipline and dealing with sin and so on and so forth, but the purpose of church discipline is not excommunication. The true purpose of church discipline is reconciliation and restoration. That's the idea. Listen, God's people need to belong to a church. The church is God's idea, it's God's plan, and God has instituted the church, and God has given us instructions with regard to church discipline, and from time to time it's necessary because of an offense and what have you, but the purpose is always reconciliation, restoration, and we rejoice in that truth, the biblical truth of reconciliation and restoration, and it's coupled there with forgiveness, and I'm mindful of what Galatians 6 tells us. It tells us this, brethren, if a man be overtaken in a fault, ye which are spiritual, notice what it says, restore such an one in the spirit of meekness, considering thyself, lest thou also be tempted, and we think about that restoration, and back a couple of summers ago, my dad preached through Psalm 23 on Wednesday evenings, and I want to remind you what the Bible says in Psalm 23. He says, he, speaking of the Lord being our shepherd, he restoreth my soul, and what a blessing to understand this evening, and then to see this picture between Jacob and Esau. I mean, again, Jacob, why did he leave? Mom said, hey, I've heard that Esau's going to kill you. You need to go a little ways, and you need to get away for a little while so that his anger will depart, and after 20 years, this reunion is given to us, and it's a reunion that's sweet. There's an embrace. The Bible says that he ran to meet him, embraced him, fell on his neck and kissed him, and they wept. Isn't that beautiful? I understand that as I look at this passage of Scripture, and I think about this event that's been provided for us, this record that's been given, what a joy it is to have that sweet communion and fellowship one with another. There are individuals, believers, that have been at odds at one another for sometime years and years and years, and they just dig in their heels, and they refuse to forgive, refuse to have any level of restoration or reconciliation, and oh, that that would never be said of us as God's people, that we'd understand that our God is ready to pardon, ready to forgive, and because we've been forgiven, that we too are to forgive others, and we think about this great example where Jacob embraced his brother. Not only did Jacob embrace his brother, but number two, if you're taking notes, Jacob explained God's blessing. Jacob explained God's blessing. He testified a little bit, begins in verse number five, he lifted up his eyes and saw the women and the children and said, who are those with thee? This is Esau asking Jacob about what he now sees, and Jacob responds and says this at the end of verse number five, the children which God hath graciously given thy servant. And he said, these are divine grace in the sight of my Lord. Peradventure, he will accept of me. And so Esau says, hey, what is all of this that I see? He sees the women and the children, he now references the droves of livestock, and it says this in verse number 9, and Esau said, I have enough, my brother, keep that thou hast unto thyself. And Jacob said, nay, I pray thee, if now I have found grace in thy sight, then receive my present at my hand, for therefore I have seen thy face, as though I had seen the face of God, and thou was pleased with me." Notice verse number 11. I read it by way of introduction, but notice it says, take, I pray thee, my blessing that is brought to thee, because God hath dealt graciously with me, and because I have enough. And he urged him, and he took it. And he said, let us take our journey, and let us go, and I will go before thee. As we look at these verses of scripture, really in verses five through 11, we see that Jacob is explaining the blessing of God. I want you to think about these 20 years, and much of what we've studied, and obviously it was a long time ago that we're studying the time that he was there in Paddan Aram, and all that took place, but as we're familiar with the text of scripture, and the record that God gives us, we find that it is absolutely true that during that period of time, that Jacob experienced some hardship. He experienced some difficulty. There were some things, some circumstances that were not what we might describe as being favorable or desirable. But we find that when Jacob and Esau have this reunion, and after the embrace, and then Jacob explains the blessing of God, I'm thankful that as I read these verses of scripture in verses five through 11, you know what you don't see? You don't see any complaining. You don't see Jacob saying to Esau, listen, let me tell you how bad it was. Let me tell you all the bad things that I experienced when I was there in Paddan Aram, and let me tell you how they weren't fair, and how this happened, and that happened, you don't read any complaining. Not only do you not read any complaining, but you find that Jacob didn't blame Esau for anything that happened. He could have been bitter at Esau. Why did he leave in the first place? Because Esau said he was gonna kill him. And he leaves. And sometimes when we experience some difficulties and hardships, we're looking for someone to put the blame on. Sometimes that's what happens in life. But I don't read that in Jacob's testimony. I read that Jacob, as he's explaining what's taken place, there's no complaining, there's no blame that's being placed upon Esau. I also recognize this. Jacob doesn't take any credit for himself. When Esau asks in verse number five, when he says he looked up his eyes and saw the women and the children and said, who are those with thee? And then in verse number eight, when he says, what meanest thou by all this drove which I met? Jacob doesn't say, yeah, it's been pretty good, man. I really made it. I mean, I went out there and I did all of this and I, that's not what Jacob says. There's no boasting. There's no complaining. There's no blaming. There's no boasting. We find that Jacob explains and he declares the goodness of God. He declares the goodness of God. We find that in this text of Scripture that he recognized it was God that had blessed him. He recognized that it was God that had graciously given him the children. Notice in verse number five, he said, the children which God hath graciously given thy servant. When he speaks about the droves, when the question is asked in verse number eight and he speaks about the present, he says in verse number 11, take, I pray thee, my blessing that is brought to thee.
